english: As if; just like; often used with comparisons (まるで〜みたいだ / まるで〜ようだ).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>まるで</ruby><ruby>何<rt>なに</rt></ruby>も<ruby>知<rt>し</rt></ruby>らないかのように<ruby>話<rt>はな</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: He spoke as if he knew nothing.

english: Continually; constantly; an adverb meaning something happens without a break (contrast: 絶え間ない as an adjective).
japanese_example: <ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>絶<rt>た</rt></ruby>え<ruby>間<rt>ま</rt></ruby>なく<ruby>降<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>り<ruby>続<rt>つづ</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: The rain continued to fall nonstop.

english: Unceasing; continuous; an adjective meaning something goes on without interruption (contrast: 絶え間なく as an adverb).
japanese_example: <ruby>絶<rt>た</rt></ruby>え<ruby>間<rt>ま</rt></ruby>ない<ruby>拍手<rt>はくしゅ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>会場<rt>かいじょう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>響<rt>ひび</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: Unceasing applause echoed through the venue.

english: Stomach; the organ for digestion (often used in medical or bodily sensation contexts).
japanese_example: <ruby>胃<rt>い</rt></ruby>が<ruby>痛<rt>いた</rt></ruby>くて、<ruby>朝<rt>あさ</rt></ruby>ごはんが<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べられなかった。
english_example: My stomach hurt, so I couldn't eat breakfast.

english: With a dull, throbbing pain; describes a persistent ache (often used with 痛む).
japanese_example: <ruby>胃<rt>い</rt></ruby>がしくしく<ruby>痛<rt>いた</rt></ruby>んで、<ruby>落<rt>お</rt></ruby>ち<ruby>着<rt>つ</rt></ruby>かなかった。
english_example: My stomach ached dully, and I couldn't settle down.

english: Castle; a fortified residence or stronghold.
japanese_example: <ruby>丘<rt>おか</rt></ruby>の<ruby>上<rt>うえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>古<rt>ふる</rt></ruby>い<ruby>城<rt>しろ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>建<rt>た</rt></ruby>っている。
english_example: An old castle stands on top of the hill.

english: Back way; secret passage; also used for a shortcut or a way to slip past something.
japanese_example: <ruby>渋滞<rt>じゅうたい</rt></ruby>を<ruby>避<rt>さ</rt></ruby>けるために<ruby>抜<rt>ぬ</rt></ruby>け<ruby>道<rt>みち</rt></ruby>を<ruby>使<rt>つか</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: To avoid traffic, I took a back road.

english: To carry or transport (something) from one place to another; used for physical movement of items.
japanese_example: <ruby>重<rt>おも</rt></ruby>い<ruby>荷物<rt>にもつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>二人<rt>ふたり</rt></ruby>で<ruby>運<rt>はこ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: We carried the heavy luggage together.

english: Great hall; a large main hall used for gatherings or ceremonies.
japanese_example: <ruby>大広間<rt>おおひろま</rt></ruby>に<ruby>学生<rt>がくせい</rt></ruby>が<ruby>集<rt>あつ</rt></ruby>まった。
english_example: The students gathered in the great hall.

english: Feast; treat; a special meal (also used in ご馳走する “to treat someone”).
japanese_example: <ruby>誕生日<rt>たんじょうび</rt></ruby>に<ruby>ご馳走<rt>ごちそう</rt></ruby>を<ruby>用意<rt>ようい</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: I prepared a feast for the birthday.

english: Tower; a tall structure (e.g., castle tower, radio tower).
japanese_example: <ruby>塔<rt>とう</rt></ruby>の<ruby>上<rt>うえ</rt></ruby>から<ruby>町<rt>まち</rt></ruby>がよく<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>えた。
english_example: From the top of the tower, the town was clearly visible.

english: Dormitory; residence hall, especially for students or employees.
japanese_example: <ruby>大学<rt>だいがく</rt></ruby>の<ruby>寮<rt>りょう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>住<rt>す</rt></ruby>み<ruby>始<rt>はじ</rt></ruby>めた。
english_example: I started living in the university dormitory.

english: Canopy; especially the canopy over a bed (天蓋付きのベッド).
japanese_example: <ruby>天蓋<rt>てんがい</rt></ruby>つきの<ruby>ベッド</ruby>が<ruby>部屋<rt>へや</rt></ruby>の<ruby>中央<rt>ちゅうおう</rt></ruby>にあった。
english_example: A canopy bed was in the center of the room.

english: Forbidden; past passive form of 禁じる used adjectivally (禁じられた〜).
japanese_example: <ruby>禁<rt>きん</rt></ruby>じられた<ruby>場所<rt>ばしょ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>入<rt>はい</rt></ruby>ってはいけない。
english_example: You must not enter a forbidden area.

english: Next to; adjacent; often used as 隣の〜 or 隣に.
japanese_example: <ruby>隣<rt>となり</rt></ruby>の<ruby>部屋<rt>へや</rt></ruby>から<ruby>声<rt>こえ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>聞<rt>き</rt></ruby>こえる。
english_example: I can hear voices from the room next door.

english: Log cabin; a small house made from logs.
japanese_example: <ruby>森<rt>もり</rt></ruby>の<ruby>中<rt>なか</rt></ruby>に<ruby>丸太小屋<rt>まるたごや</rt></ruby>が<ruby>ぽつん</ruby>と<ruby>建<rt>た</rt></ruby>っていた。
english_example: A lone log cabin stood in the forest.

english: To visit; to call on someone (can also mean “to ask,” but written as 尋ねる for “inquire”).
japanese_example: <ruby>週末<rt>しゅうまつ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>祖母<rt>そぼ</rt></ruby>の<ruby>家<rt>いえ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>訪<rt>たず</rt></ruby>ねた。
english_example: I visited my grandmother's house on the weekend.

english: Listing form for examples of actions/states; often paired as 〜たり〜たりする and frequently used with past forms.
japanese_example: <ruby>映画<rt>えいが</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>たり<ruby>料理<rt>りょうり</rt></ruby>したりして<ruby>過<rt>す</rt></ruby>ごした。
english_example: I spent the time doing things like watching movies and cooking.

english: Flying; an attributive form meaning “that flies” (e.g., 空飛ぶ車).
japanese_example: <ruby>空飛<rt>そらと</rt></ruby>ぶ<ruby>車<rt>くるま</rt></ruby>なんて、<ruby>まだ</ruby><ruby>夢<rt>ゆめ</rt></ruby>みたいだ。
english_example: A flying car still feels like a dream.

english: Six (counter for long cylindrical objects such as bottles, pens, trees).
japanese_example: <ruby>ペン</ruby>を<ruby>六本<rt>ろっぽん</rt></ruby><ruby>買<rt>か</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: I bought six pens.

english: Four (counter for small items); also often read よっこ depending on speaker and context.
japanese_example: <ruby>りんご</ruby>を<ruby>四個<rt>よんこ</rt></ruby><ruby>箱<rt>はこ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>入<rt>い</rt></ruby>れた。
english_example: I put four apples into the box.

english: Broom; used for sweeping (and as a fantasy “flying broom”).
japanese_example: <ruby>箒<rt>ほうき</rt></ruby>で<ruby>廊下<rt>ろうか</rt></ruby>を<ruby>掃<rt>は</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: I swept the hallway with a broom.

english: Spell; incantation; words chanted to produce magical effects.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>呪文<rt>じゅもん</rt></ruby>を<ruby>唱<rt>とな</rt></ruby>えて<ruby>扉<rt>とびら</rt></ruby>を<ruby>開<rt>あ</rt></ruby>けた。
english_example: He chanted a spell and opened the door.

english: Cane or staff; also a wand in fantasy contexts, depending on the situation.
japanese_example: <ruby>老<rt>ろう</rt></ruby><ruby>人<rt>じん</rt></ruby>は<ruby>杖<rt>つえ</rt></ruby>をついて<ruby>歩<rt>ある</rt></ruby>いた。
english_example: The elderly person walked using a cane.

english: Top-grade; highest quality; often used as 最高級の〜.
japanese_example: <ruby>最高級<rt>さいこうきゅう</rt></ruby>の<ruby>素材<rt>そざい</rt></ruby>で<ruby>作<rt>つく</rt></ruby>られた<ruby>椅子<rt>いす</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: This chair is made from top-grade materials.

hiragana: いえにかえったとたん
english: The moment (someone) got home; とたん expresses an immediate change right after an action.
japanese_example: <ruby>家<rt>いえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>帰<rt>かえ</rt></ruby>ったとたん、<ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>降<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>り<ruby>出<rt>だ</rt></ruby>した。
english_example: The moment I got home, it started to rain.

english: Storeroom; storage shed/closet used for keeping items.
japanese_example: <ruby>古<rt>ふる</rt></ruby>い<ruby>道具<rt>どうぐ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>物置<rt>ものおき</rt></ruby>にしまってある。
english_example: Old tools are put away in the storeroom.

english: To push in; cram; force something into a space by pushing.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>荷物<rt>にもつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>棚<rt>たな</rt></ruby>に<ruby>押<rt>お</rt></ruby>し<ruby>込<rt>こ</rt></ruby>んだ。
english_example: He crammed the luggage onto the shelf.

english: To lock (with a key); literally “to put on a lock,” commonly said for doors and windows.
japanese_example: <ruby>出<rt>で</rt></ruby>かける<ruby>前<rt>まえ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>ドア</ruby>に<ruby>鍵<rt>かぎ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>掛<rt>か</rt></ruby>けた。
english_example: Before going out, I locked the door.

english: To remove or detach; also “to miss” (a guess/aim) or “to exclude,” depending on context.
japanese_example: <ruby>席<rt>せき</rt></ruby>を<ruby>外<rt>はず</rt></ruby>す<ruby>間<rt>あいだ</rt></ruby>、<ruby>荷物<rt>にもつ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>見<rt>み</rt></ruby>ていて。
english_example: While I'm away from my seat, watch my bags.

english: Whether ~ or not; even if; often used as 〜ようが〜まいが to mean “no matter whether…”.
japanese_example: <ruby>雨<rt>あめ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>降<rt>ふ</rt></ruby>ろうが、<ruby>予定<rt>よてい</rt></ruby>どおり<ruby>出発<rt>しゅっぱつ</rt></ruby>する。
english_example: Even if it rains, we'll leave as planned.

english: A household; a family as a unit (e.g., 一家全員).
japanese_example: <ruby>一家<rt>いっか</rt></ruby>で<ruby>旅行<rt>りょこう</rt></ruby>に<ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: The whole family went on a trip.

english: For ~; from ~’s standpoint; marks whose perspective or interests something is evaluated by.
japanese_example: <ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>にとって、<ruby>この</ruby><ruby>経験<rt>けいけん</rt></ruby>は<ruby>大切<rt>たいせつ</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: For me, this experience is important.

english: Idiomatic: “I don’t care; not my problem”; blunt and dismissive, often used in arguments.
japanese_example: <ruby>そんな</ruby><ruby>こと</ruby>、<ruby>知<rt>し</rt></ruby>ったことはない。
english_example: I don't care about that; it's not my problem.

english: Not even one; used with negation to emphasize zero quantity (一つも〜ない).
japanese_example: <ruby>質問<rt>しつもん</rt></ruby>の<ruby>答<rt>こた</rt></ruby>えが<ruby>一<rt>ひと</rt></ruby>つも<ruby>分<rt>わ</rt></ruby>からなかった。
english_example: I couldn't understand even a single answer to the questions.

english: Without doing ~; a written/formal equivalent of 〜ないで, attaching to the verb stem (e.g., 食べずに).
japanese_example: <ruby>朝<rt>あさ</rt></ruby>ごはんを<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べずに<ruby>学校<rt>がっこう</rt></ruby>へ<ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: I went to school without eating breakfast.

english: Colloquial “even if/though,” roughly equivalent to 〜ても; can sound casual or emphatic.
japanese_example: <ruby>今<rt>いま</rt></ruby>から<ruby>走<rt>はし</rt></ruby>ったって、<ruby>間<rt>ま</rt></ruby>に<ruby>合<rt>あ</rt></ruby>わないよ。
english_example: Even if you run from now, you won't make it in time.

english: No problem; unfazed; a casual word meaning something doesn’t bother you at all.
japanese_example: <ruby>これ</ruby>くらいの<ruby>寒<rt>さむ</rt></ruby>さなら<ruby>へっちゃら</ruby>だ。
english_example: This level of cold doesn't bother me at all.

english: Magical folk/people; a group or lineage associated with magic (fictional or stylized term).
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>魔法族<rt>まほうぞく</rt></ruby>の<ruby>家系<rt>かけい</rt></ruby>に<ruby>生<rt>う</rt></ruby>まれた。
english_example: He was born into a magical family line.

english: A single drop; counter for drops of liquid (often used as 一滴も with negation).
japanese_example: <ruby>血<rt>ち</rt></ruby>が<ruby>一滴<rt>いってき</rt></ruby><ruby>床<rt>ゆか</rt></ruby>に<ruby>落<rt>お</rt></ruby>ちた。
english_example: A single drop of blood fell onto the floor.

english: To call (someone/something); to summon or name, depending on context.
japanese_example: <ruby>困<rt>こま</rt></ruby>ったら<ruby>私<rt>わたし</rt></ruby>を<ruby>呼<rt>よ</rt></ruby>んでね。
english_example: If you have trouble, call me.

english: Blood; also used figuratively for lineage or temperament in some expressions.
japanese_example: <ruby>血<rt>ち</rt></ruby>が<ruby>止<rt>と</rt></ruby>まらないので、<ruby>すぐ</ruby><ruby>病院<rt>びょういん</rt></ruby>へ<ruby>行<rt>い</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: The bleeding wouldn't stop, so I went to the hospital right away.

english: Race; ethnicity; a sociological term for human groupings (usage can be sensitive depending on context).
japanese_example: <ruby>人種<rt>じんしゅ</rt></ruby>による<ruby>差別<rt>さべつ</rt></ruby>は<ruby>許<rt>ゆる</rt></ruby>されない。
english_example: Discrimination based on race is not allowed.

english: Family; one’s family members as a group.
japanese_example: <ruby>家族<rt>かぞく</rt></ruby>と<ruby>一緒<rt>いっしょ</rt></ruby>に<ruby>夕食<rt>ゆうしょく</rt></ruby>を<ruby>食<rt>た</rt></ruby>べた。
english_example: I ate dinner together with my family.

english: Wizard; magician; a person who uses magic (general term).
japanese_example: <ruby>魔法使<rt>まほうつか</rt></ruby>いは<ruby>杖<rt>つえ</rt></ruby>を<ruby>手<rt>て</rt></ruby>に<ruby>取<rt>と</rt></ruby>った。
english_example: The wizard took a wand in hand.

english: Expression showing contempt, surprise, or disbelief about something; often like “something like…” or “to think that…”.
japanese_example: <ruby>彼<rt>かれ</rt></ruby>が<ruby>嘘<rt>うそ</rt></ruby>をつくなんて<ruby>信<rt>しん</rt></ruby>じられない。
english_example: I can't believe he would lie.

english: From the perspective of ~; as far as ~ is concerned; highlights the subject’s viewpoint.
japanese_example: <ruby>親<rt>おや</rt></ruby>にしてみれば、<ruby>子供<rt>こども</rt></ruby>の<ruby>安全<rt>あんぜん</rt></ruby>が<ruby>一番<rt>いちばん</rt></ruby>だ。
english_example: From a parent's perspective, a child's safety comes first.
